sentence: Benchmarks closed in the green for the second consecutive session following broad based gains.
All the key sectors of the S&P 500 finished in the green.
S&P 500 posted its biggest two-session percentage increase since August.
However, oil prices gave up earlier gains to end in the red after chances of a deal on production cuts reduced.
Fall in oil prices curtailed some of the gains for the energy sector.

For a look at the issues currently facing the markets, make sure to read today's Ahead of Wall Street article

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) advanced 1.4%, or 222.57 points, to close at 16,196.41.
The Standard & Poor's 500 (S&P 500) increased nearly 1.7% to close at 1,895.58.
The tech-laden Nasdaq Composite Index closed at 4,435.96, rising 2.3%.
The fear-gauge CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) decreased 5.1% to settle at 24.11.
A total of around 8.6 billion shares were traded on Tuesday, lower than the last 20-session average of 9.6 billion shares.
Advancers outpaced declining stocks on the NYSE.
For 80% stocks that advanced, only 19% declined.
The Consumer Discretionary Select Sector SPDR (XLY) advanced 2.4%, and was the highest gainers among the S&P 500 sectors.

Key components including Amazon.com, Inc. ( AMZN ), The Walt Disney Company ( DIS ), The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ), Comcast Corporation ( CMCSA ) and McDonald's Corp. ( MCD ) increased 2.8%, 2.7%, 1.9%, 1.2% and 1.1% respectively.
While the SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT) rose 4%, it's highest in a day since 2011.
Also, the Industrial Select Sector SPDR (XLI) gained 2% and was the second biggest gainer among the S&P 500 sectors.
Dow components The Boeing Company ( BA ) and Caterpillar Inc. ( CAT ) climbed 3.7% and 3.3% respectively.

Some of the other key stocks from this sector, including General Electric Company ( GE ), 3M Company ( MMM ), Honeywell International Inc. ( HON ) and United Technologies Corporation ( UTX ) increased 2.1%, 1%, 1.4% and 0.6% respectively.
Additionally, gains in technology stocks helped the Nasdaq to finish with healthy gains.
Apple Inc's ( AAPL ) shares rose 2.8% after the tech giant said that it will sell bonds worth of $10-12 billion in order to pay dividends and to support its repurchase program.
The Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) increased 1.8%.
While Dow component Microsoft Corp ( MSFT ) advanced 1.2%.
Alphabet Inc ( GOOGL ), AT&T Inc ( T ) and Verizon Communications Inc. ( VZ ) increased 1.5%, 0.5% and 0.3% respectively.
Moreover, financial stocks continued to rally on Tuesday and the Financial Services Select Sector SPDR (XLFS) improved 1.9%.
Dow components JPMorgan Chase & Co. ( JPM ) and Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. ( GS ) increased 1.5% and 2% respectively.
Meanwhile, earlier in the day, increase in oil prices helped boost energy shares following hopes of an agreement between Russia and key OPEC members like Saudi Arabia on a production cut.
However, oil prices failed to hold on to gains after Russia, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Qatar said crude output levels will remain constant, indicating no possibility of production cut.
Chances of the production cut declined after Iran declined to make any immediate production cuts.
While the WTI crude fell 1.4% to $29.04 per barrel, Brent crude decreased 3.7% to $32.18 a barrel.
Despite fall in oil prices the Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE) increased 1%.
Dow components, Exxon Mobil Corp ( XOM ) increased 0.2% but Chevron Corp ( CVX ) decreased 0.7%.
However, decline in oil prices had a positive impact on transportation stocks.
The Dow Jones Transportation Average rose 2.3%, crossing above 50-day moving average level, which was last seen on Dec 1.
Key stocks from the sector including FedEx Corporation (FDX), Norfolk Southern Corporation (NSC) and Alaska Air Group, Inc. (ALK) rose 2.7%, 2% and 1.7%, respectively.
Separately, China's new yuan loans reached its highest ever level of 2.51 trillion yuan.
Total social financing almost doubled in January 3.42 to trillion yuan.
The increase in the metric reflects Beijing's efforts to boost market liquidity ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday.

In economic news, the Empire State Manufacturing Survey Index came in at a negative 16.64 in February, worse than the consensus estimate of a negative 8.5. Business activity for New York manufacturers declined for the seventh consecutive month in November.
The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) reported that home builder sentiment index (HMI) fell from January's 61 to 58 in February, but was above the satisfactory level of 50.

Meanwhile, speaking at the University of Delaware, Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker said: "It might prove prudent to wait until the inflation data are stronger before we undertake a second rate hike."
Harker added that the Fed will reach a position to affect a rate hike in second half of 2016 following the stabilization of financial markets and energy prices.
